div3.head: Latest Northern and European news.
div3.p:
--By arrivals to-day we have received Northern papers of yesterday.
I send you a synopsis of the news the papers contain:

Halifax, March 6.--The steamship Canada has arrived with Liverpool mail dates to the 22d, and telegraph dates from Liverpool, received at Queenstown, up to the 23d February; being two days later than were received by former arrivals.

In the House of Commons, Mr. O'Donohoe has censured the Government for not having prevented breaches of neutrality and British vessels from running the blockade.
The Solicitor General had said that private vessels might carry articles contraband of war, at their own risk.
The Spanish squadron starts for the Pacific on the first of April.
It is announced that Italy will be recognized by Prussia.
The betrothal of the King of Portugal to the sister of the late Queen of Portugal is announced.
Numerous arrests have taken place in Athens of senators, officers, advocates, and journalists, and the rebellion still continues.
At Paris, on the 22d February, the Bourse was firm, and rentes were quoted at 70.35.

At Havre the sales of cotton for the week were 18,000 bales, with a firm and buoyant market.
Orleans tres ordisaire was quoted at 105a16Sf.
The stock of cotton was 93,500 bales.

div4.head: Latest from Liverpool, (by telegraph to Queenstown, Feb. 23.)
div4.p: --The sales of cotton on yesterday were 8,000 bales, of which 6,000 were taken by speculators and exporters.--The market closed firm at unchanged quotations.
At London on the 21st Feb. consols were quoted at 98¼. American securities were unchanged.

Mr. Slidell has had an interview with the Emperor Napoleon, and communicated to him correct and enlightened views in relation to the affairs of the Confederacy.
The Emperor is said to have replied that he hoped the war would soon close, as it was inflicting serious injury to France.

Advices from Vera Cruz to the 20th Feb. have been received in New York.
They state that negotiations at the city of Mexico had failed to accomplish the ends desired.
It is stated that Mexico is again the victim of treachery.
Forces of the allies have been allowed to pass the strongholds and occupy the strongest fortified points.

Intelligence from Havana to the 1st of March has been received.
The statement that there has been no armed resistance to the allied invaders of Mexico is confirmed.--There is great scarcity of provisions at Vera Cruz.

Washington, March 5.--Advices from the lower Potomac state that the Confederates are concentrating a large force opposite Hooker's Division, and it is supposed that a large number of Southern troops have recently arrived.
Salt Lake City, March 4.--Brigham Young has been re-elected Governor of Utah.

Springfield, Mo., March 1.--On Wednesday night 300 Confederates surprised Capt. Montgomery at Kittsville, and several Federals were killed and seventy horses were taken.
It is believed that Generals Van-Dorn, Price, McCulloch and Pike will overrun the country.

Louisville, March 4.--Two bridges at Nashville and the Decatur Railroad have been destroyed.
The largest boats continue to navigate the rivers.

Chicago, March 4.--Columbus was burning from Friday until Sunday.
A portion was still on fire.
A large number of the cannon were thrown into the river.
A portion of the works were mined.
Nineteen thousand Confederate troops had left by railroad, and they had destroyed the railroad track and bridges for six miles.
Charlestown, Va., March 5.--Last night a part of the Michigan cavalry advanced to Perryville, and ambushed and returned with nine horses.

Cincinnati, March 5.--A dispatch from Nashville states that the Mayor has issued a proclamation, in which he states that every assurance has been given by General Buel, (the Federal commander,) that he will guarantee the safety and protection to persons and property in Nashville.
The city is quiet.--The Post-Office will open to-morrow.

div3.p: The Evacuation of Columbus Confirmed — The Federals near New Madrid--Com. Hollins and his Gunboats.

Memphis, March 4.--Columbus was entirely evacuated on Sunday afternoon. Everything not carried away was burnt.
Many buildings, including private residences, were burnt.

The Federals, 19,000 strong, under the command of Gen. Pope, appeared in front of New Madrid, five miles from the river, on Monday afternoon. Com. Hollins and his gunboats fired upon and shelled them and kept them back.

The Federal lines extend around the town for upwards of a mile.
Up to four o'clock on Monday afternoon the Federals had made no response.
We continued to shell them from our gunboats.
It was supposed that the enemy would make an attack on Tuesday morning, and an attack from the enemy's gunboats was momentarily expected.
Island No.10 has been fortified.
It is reported from Nashville that large numbers of negroes have been taken off by the Federal gunboats.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p: --The latest advices from East Tennessee state that Gen. Schoopff is making arrangements to advance by Big Creek Gap. The recent demonstration at the Cumberland Gap was a feint.
There has been no quorum in the Tennessee Legislature yet. Business of importance is awaiting final action.

The final evacuation of Columbus took place on Sunday afternoon. The provisions, ammunition, and nearly all the guns, were saved.
All the buildings occupied by the military, and many others, were not burned.
Our river defences are progressing rapidly.
An order was issued on Monday for the destruction of the town of New Madrid, as a military necessity.
In a recent skirmish at Keythoden, Missouri, the Confederates took ten prisoners, killed twenty-five of the enemy, burned 280 wagons, and captured a number of horses, mules, clothing, &c., &c.
There is nothing later from New Madrid.

div3.head: Reported battle in Missouri.
div3.p:
--The Captain of the steamer Vicksburg reached here this evening, from New Madrid.
He states that the scouts brought in a copy of the St. Louis Republican, of a recent date, which states that Gen. Price had a fight with the enemy, and whipped them, killing about 1,000, taking many prisoners, and put the enemy to flight.
General Price was in full pursuit of them towards St. Louis.
This statement of the Captain is communicated to the press more with the hope that it may be true, than with much faith in the accuracy of it.

div3.head: The Southern cause in Georgia.
div3.p: --The intelligence received here, from different portions of the cotton-growing sections of the State, confirm the opinion that no cotton, or very little, will be planted this year in this State.

Intelligence obtained from the Adjutant General's office, in Milledgeville, announces that Georgia will furnish 25 per cent. more troops than have been required as her quota by the Confederate States Government.

div3.head: Interesting from Havana.
div3.p:
--The Charleston Courier of this morning publishes some interesting intelligence from Havana, obtained by a recent arrival at that port.
It may not be imprudent to state that there has been a recent accession to the stock of dry goods, medicines, &c., in that city.

div3.head:
[Special Dispatch to the Richmond Dispatch.]
meeting of the General M. E. Conference Postponed.
div3.p: --The Southern Christian Advocate has a letter from Bishop Andrew, postponing the meeting of the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, (which was to have assembled at New Orleans on the 1st of April,) to a future time and place, to be agreed on by the Bishop.

div3.head: Incorrect report — Fernandina shelled by the Yankees.
div3.p: --A special dispatch from Savannah, says that Brunswick, Ga., has not been burnt, as was reported.

On Sunday last, as the train was leaving Fernandina, the enemy's gunboat was shelling the town.
One of the shells fell in a passenger car and killed two persons and wounded another.
The town has been evacuated, and is now in the possession of the Federals.

div3.head: Sailing of a British steamer.
div3.p: --The Charleston papers of this morning state that the British steamer Rinaldo sailed on Thursday for Hampton Roads.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 57, page 3.

div3.head: Elizabeth City.
div3.p:
From a gentlemen just from Elizabeth City, we learn that the Enemy has not yet attempted to occupy the town, but that they have frequently threatened to destroy it.--Three gun-boats have been anchored in the river, near the point where the small battery was placed.
The men are allowed to go ashore, about a mile below the town, and for some time have been guilty of daily outrages upon the farmers living in the vicinity, killing their stock and stealing everything that comes within reach.
No kind of private property is respected.
The pickets of the 3rd Georgia regiment are stationed in the town, and are ordered to fire upon the Yankees if they attempt to enter it. In return, the Yankees threaten if a single man is fired on, the town will be immediately destroyed.
Nearly all the inhabitants have left.
Our sick and wounded have been removed to Norfolk.

div3.head: Martial law.
div3.p:
In another column will be found two general orders, issued under martial law, from the Headquarters of the Department of Henrico, containing instructions to the proprietors of hotels and boarding-houses, livery stable keepers and owners of backs, drivers of stage coaches, and to citizens generally.
The peculiar force and necessity of these orders will be manifest at a glance.
At this time every man within the military limit, or who passes its lines, should be held to strict accountability, and should undergo a rigid examination as to his business and purpose.
While this may offer slight annoyance to some, its good effect upon the public welfare will render its disagreeable features of little moment to true and loyal people.
It is a pity each regulations had not been made long ago. They would have kept from the confederate Capital a number of prowling Yankee spies, who have passed with impunity from point to point throughout the South, By Order No. 5, it will be seen that the city of Richmond is divided into two military districts; that Col. John O. Porter is appointed Provost Marshal, and Capts. A. C. Godwin and J. C. Maynard, Assistants.
Samuel Macubbin is appointed Chief of Police.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p:
The discussion of the bill providing for the destruction of cotton and tobacco about to fall into the hands of the enemy, was the principal matter before the House yesterday.
In the Senate, secret session, the House bill in the destruction of cotton was laid upon the table for the present, inasmuch as the Senate has a bill of its own upon the subject.
It has been already published.
The House bill relating to the public printing was passed by the Senate and returned.

div3.head: An editor in the field.
div3.p:
The editor of the Montgomery Advertisers Mr. Samuel G. Reid, has issued a patriotic and stirring appeal to the people of Alabama, to come forward and assist in the defence of the country.
He announces himself a volunteer for the war. Mr. Reid is an intrepid and have man — a true son of the South, and will do as good service to his country with his sword, as he has heretofore done with his pen. Success to his efforts.

div3.head: Col. Forney.
div3.p:
Col. John H. Forney, of the 10th Alabama Regiment, who was seriously wounded in the battle of Drainsville, has been made a Brigadier General. Col. Forney was an officer in the old army, and at one time commandant at West Point.
He entered the service as Brevet 2d Lieutenant, 7th infantry, July 1st, 1852. He was among the first to resign his commission in order to offer his services to his State--Alabama.

div3.head: Gen. Winder.
div3.p:
The appointment of Gen. J. H. Winder, as Brigadier-General, was to-day confirmed by the Senate.
He has for some time been Acting Brigadier, and commandant of the Department of Henrico.

div3.head: Married.
div3.p:
On Wednesday last, by Rev. Mr. Christian.
Hugh Douglas McCABE.
of Leesburg, to Ricotta E., eldest daughter of Samuel S. and Mary A. R. Clark, of Henrico.
Leesburg paper please copy.

div4.p: At the residence of her mother, in Fredericksburg, on the 6th inst., at 8 o'clock P.M., Mrs. Mary Virginia Kips, consort of Wm. James Epps, aged 21 years.

Her funeral will take place at the residence of Capt. Thos. C. Epps, this day, at 3½ o'clk P. M., corner of 1st and Baker streets. The friends and acquaintances of the family are requested to attend without further notice.
Lynchburg papers please copy.
Suddenly, yesterday, at a quarter after 4 o'clock, Mr. Peter H. Montague.

The deceased was a member of the Fire Brigade, company D, and while guarding the reel which was left at the corner of Broad and 9th streets, fell and expired in a few moments.
He leaves a wife and two interesting children to mourn their loss.
The funeral will take place on Sunday, 11 o'clock, at Olay Street M. R. Church, of which for years he had been a consistent member.

The attention of company D.
is directed to the above, and they are requested to attend the funeral with helmets and halts.
Other companies also invited to attend.

By order.
Jno. E. Sheppard,
Commander Company D.
On the 7th instant, of pneumonia, Patrich Moran, in the 40th year of his age.

His funeral will take place at the residence of Mr. Michael Purcell, on 17th street, at 3 o'clock Sunday, the 9th inst. His friends, and those of Mr. Purcell, are invited to attend without further notices.

list.head: General Orders no. 4.--
list.item:
I. The proprietors of hotels and boarding-houses will forth with report to the Provost Marshal the names of all guests at their houses, and the names of all white persons in their employment.
A list of arrivals will also be furnished to the Provost Marshal twice every day, at the hours of 10 A. M. and 8 P. M.

II.
Livery stable keepers, and owners of hacks and other public vehicles, will report to the Provost Marshal the location of their stables and the number of their horses, hacks, &c. They will also make daily reports of persons from the surrounding country putting horses or carriages in their stables.

III.
No person is permitted to pass beyond the corporate limits of the city in a hack or other vehicle, or on horseback, without a passport.
Drivers of stage-coaches are specially forbidden from taking passengers at any point within the ten miles of country under martial law, either to transport them into the city or to distant places, unless such persons have passports.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't. Of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 5.--I. Colonel John C. Porter is appointed Provost marshal of the city of Richmond, and Capts. A. C. Godwin and J. C. Maynard are appointed Assistant Provost Marshals.
All communications, verbal or written, concerning passports or the location of guards, must be made to the Provost Marshal.

II.
The city of Richmond is divided into two military districts, by a line commencing at Mayo's Bridge and running up 14th to Main street, thence up Main to Governor or 13th street to 12th street, thence up 12th street to the limits of the city.
The district east of said line of division is under command of Capt. A. C. Godwin, and the district west of said line is under the command of Capt. J. C. Maynard.

III.
Samuel Macubbin is appointed Chief of Police.

div3.head: Stuart's Horse Artillery.
div3.p:
Wanted--one hundred men, for the above splendid Battery of eight pieces — Blakely Guas and Howitzers — to act as Horse Artillery.
Every cannoned mounted; with Gen. Stuart's Cavalry Brigade, Army of Potomac.
I am acting under the following orders:

div4.p:
"Capt. Jno. Esten Cook, Volunteer Aid to Brig. Gen. Stuart, is hereby ordered to proceed to Richmond, on recruiting service for the Stuart Horse Artillery.
He will be governed by the rules and regulations for recruiting of the A. and I. General's Dept. C. S. A.

closer.signed:
"By command of Gen. Stewart.
"W. E. Towles, A. A. A. Gen'l."

div4.p:
This will be the finest battery in the service.
Every cannoneer is mounted, with horse and accoutrements furnished by the Government.
The company, which is nearly made up, will be increased to 150 men, and as soon as the legal number is obtained there will be an election of officers, and the battery will take the field.

The ordinary bounty of $50 paid.
All persons wishing to join this company are requested to address me by letter, at Richmond, or apply at the Recalling Office, opposite Goddin's Hall, 11th street, to me or to Robert D. Ward, Esq., who is associated with me.

--All members of the Hanover Artillery now at home on furlough are required, by order of Major-General Magruder, to return to their company immediately.
All who are absent from the company on account of sickness, must return, if able to do any duty.
All recruits for the company will apply to me, at my residence, where they will be mustered in and receive certificates to enable them to get transportation free.

div3.head: By the President of the Confederate States of America.

div4.head: A proclamation.

dateline.name: Adj't and Insp. General Office, Richmond,

list.head: General Orders, no. 9.
list.item:
I. The following Proclamation of the President is published for the information of all concerned:
proclamation.
"By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in threatened with invasion, I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that Martial law is hereby extended, over the city of Richmond, and the adjoining and surrounding country to the distance of ten miles, and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, with the exception of that of the Mayor of the city, and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus within the said city, and surrounding country to the distance aforesaid.
In faith whereof, I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal at the city of Richmond, on this first day of March in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
[Signed,] Jefferson Davis"

II. Brigadier General J. H. Winder, Commanding Department of Henrico, "is charged with the due execution of the foregoing proclamation." He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders:
All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and the establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court Martial--provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be by the sentence of regimental Court Martial as directed in the 67th Article of War.

div4.p: By command of the Secretary of War.
S. Cooper,
Adjutant and Inspector General.
mh 3--1w

div4.head: Headquarters Department of Henrico,

list.head: General order, no. 3.
list.item: I. By virtue of authority conferred by General Orders, No. 3, Adjutant and Inspector General's Office, March 1st, 1862. Captain A. C. Godwin, is appointed Provost Marshal of the city of Richmond and the adjoining and surrounding country for the distance of ten miles.

II.
The Passport Office is continued at its present location, under the charge of the Provost Marshal.

III.
The distillation and distribution of vinous, spirituous, and malt liquors, or other intoxicating beverage, is absolutely prohibited.
This order will be strictly enforced by the Provost Marshal against all persons found distilling, selling giving away, or in any manner disposing of such beverages.

IV.
All persons, of every degree, except those in the service of the State or Confederate States, having arms in their possession will deliver the same to the Ordnance Department on or before the th of March, 1862, otherwise they will be seized and taken possession of by the Provost Marshal.
Arms belonging to the State of Virginia will be delivered to Colonel Dimmock at the State Arsenal, in this city.
The word arms embraces to its meaning swords, bayonets, rifles, double barrel shot guns, and pistols of such size as may be useful in the field.
Compensation will be made for private arms delivered up or taken for public use, and Government arms, not in the public service, will be receipted for.

div3.head: A proclamation.
div3.p: Whereas, the Congress of the Confederate States has by law vested in the President the power to suspend the writ of habeas corpus in cities in danger of attack by the enemy:

Now, therefore.
I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do hereby proclaim that martial law is extended over the cities of Norfolk and Ports month and the surrounding country to the distance of ten miles from said cities, and all civil jurisdiction and the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus are hereby declared to be suspended within the limits aforesaid.
This proclamation will remain in force until otherwise ordered.
In faith whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal, at the City of Richmond, on this twenty seventh day of February, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two
[Signed.] Jefferson Davis

div3.p: in pursuance of the provisions of an act of the General Assembly, entitled "an act to constitute a corps more effectually to collect the public arms of the State and Confederate States," passed February 12, 1862, the Sheriffs and Sergeants of the several counties and corporations are required forthwith to collect, or cause the public arms of the State to be collected and returned, according to the provisions of the act recited.
No person cansequire the right of property to public arms by purchase, possession or otherwise: therefore, all such claims must be disregarded.

The Governor feels assured that he may, as he , confidently rely upon the patriotism of the officers who are now called upon to render an important public service, under a most pressing public emergency, and doubts not that it will be rendered with promptitude and energy.

div3.p: Having been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or a Regiment of Heavy Artillery, for three years or the war, I should be glad to confer with Captains who have companies not yet mustered into the service, and also those who desire to raise companies.

Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection, by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence, from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered.
Twelve months men can re-enlist, singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty.
To those citizens who have not reported themselves, as required, and who will in a few days be drafted, now is the time, and the last, to serve as volunteers.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies, from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office under the St. Charles Hotel, Old Dominion Insurance Company, Main street. City Post-Office, Box 877.

No person can acquire right of properly in these arms, either by purchase, possession or otherwise.

Any person subject to militia duty, who shall fall to deliver said arms, if in his possession, will at once be drafted into the military service for the war, and those not subject to such duty, will be fined not less than ten dollars.

The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery to be enlisted for the war. We are happy now to announce that we have procured the guns, which will be ready for us, together with all equipments, as soon as our company is mustered into service.
To those who would like to go along with us and share with us the fortunes of this war, we earnestly appeal to come forward now and join us at office.

Application may be made at our Recruiting office, on Main, between 7th and 8th streets, or at the store of Johnston & Bransford.

--The undersigned expects to fill up his company in a few days, with the best material, and those disposed to unite with him had better do so at once.
To be a volunteer is a noble, proud position.
To be a drafted, forced, coerced, militiaman, is almost disgraceful, when it is remembered that we are engaged in the defence of our homes and all we hold most dear in life.

As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at once at the rendezvous, northwest corner of Cary and 11th streets, where one or more of the undersigned can always be seen.

div3.head: Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of bearing arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, and call upon our follow-citizens to come forward and aid us in getting it up.

We went, if possible, to raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns, and think this enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Crenshaw Wollen Company Goods, will be furnished free, and the bounty of $50 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendezvous at the warehouse on the Basin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co.'s, where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruits maintained free of all expense.
The traveling expenses of recruits from the country to the city will be paid.

The Fayette Artillery of our of the best equipped companies in the service.
A liberal bounty will be given to recruit.

are, however, required.

The draft will, within a few days, compel those to take the field who fall to respond to their country's call in this, her hour of peril.

I therefore request all persons having any such arms in their possession to leave them at my office, at the City Hall, within the next twenty days, as the penalty is heavy for a failure to do so.

Each man will be paid Fifty Dollars bounty money when enlisted, and have his uniform furnished.
Now is the time to rally for the defence of our country against the base Yankee invaders.
